BSW : Predictive Models with Tidymodels Approach

Published

January 26, 2023

Modified

January 26, 2023

1. OVERVIEW

An overview of predictive model based on Diamond data set includes in ggplot2 package.

Reminder : Predictive Modelling Process
  • business problem
    • analytical data mart
  • data preparation
  • data exploration
  • data sampling
  • model fitting
  • model evaluation
  • model assessment
  • model comparison

2. R PACKAGE REQUIRED

Conventional R packages for predictive modelling :

  • caret (classification and regression training) - retired package

  • mlr3

  • rpart (recursive partitioning)

  • etc.

Focus points for tidymodels package

  • integrated, modular, extensible set of packages

  • framework facilitates in creation of predicative stochastic

  • parallel execution for tasks - resampling, cross-validation, parameter tuning.

tidyverse - importing, wrangling, visualising data

tidymodels - sampling, calibrating, modelling and assessing models.

2.1 Load R Packages

Show the code 
pacman::p_load(tidymodels, tidyverse)

3. DATA

3.1 Acquire Data Source

This study will be based on fictitious data set available in ggplot2.

Highlights of the data set
  1. x

3.2 Import Data

3.2.1 Read Data into R

data() is used to load diamonds data set from ggplot2 package.

data(diamonds)

3.2.1.2 inspect data

3.3 Data Sampling

create different types of resamples and corresponding classes for their analysis.

initial_split( ) creates single binary split of the data into a training set and testing set.

prop .6 means 60% for training( ) and remaining for testing( )

!!!!! strata’s value is the variable that applicable to most variables?

Show the code 
set.seed(1243)
diamonds_split <- diamonds %>%
  select(c(1:7)) %>%
  initial_split(prop = .6,
                strata = price)

training_data <- training(diamonds_split)
testing_data <- testing(diamonds_split)

create cross-validation data sets : rsample method

to prepare the training data set into for 3-fold cross-validation.

Show the code 
vfold_data <- vfold_cv(training_data,
                       v = 3,
                       repeats = 1,
                       strata = price)
Show the code 
vfold_data %>% 
  mutate(df_ana = map(splits, analysis),
         df_ass = map(splits, assessment))
#  3-fold cross-validation using stratification 
# A tibble: 3 × 4
  splits                id    df_ana                df_ass               
  <list>                <chr> <list>                <list>               
1 <split [21576/10788]> Fold1 <tibble [21,576 × 7]> <tibble [10,788 × 7]>
2 <split [21576/10788]> Fold2 <tibble [21,576 × 7]> <tibble [10,788 × 7]>
3 <split [21576/10788]> Fold3 <tibble [21,576 × 7]> <tibble [10,788 × 7]>

data pre-processing and feature engineering : recipes method

working with recipe

!!!!! step_log(all_outcomes) = log transform on prices = all values for strata?

step_poly(degree = ) depends on the curve?

Show the code 
processed_data <- recipe(
  price ~ .,
  data = training_data) %>%
  step_log(all_outcomes()) %>%
  step_normalize(all_predictors(),
                 -all_nominal()) %>%
  step_dummy(all_nominal()) %>%
  step_poly(carat, degree = 2)
Show the code 
prep(processed_data)
Recipe

Inputs:

      role #variables
   outcome          1
 predictor          6

Training data contained 32364 data points and no missing data.

Operations:

Log transformation on price [trained]
Centering and scaling for carat, depth, table [trained]
Dummy variables from cut, color, clarity [trained]
Orthogonal polynomials on carat [trained]

Remarks :

Changes only made to the training data.

Show the code 
juiced_data <- juice(prep(processed_data))
names(juiced_data)
 [1] "depth"        "table"        "price"        "cut_1"        "cut_2"       
 [6] "cut_3"        "cut_4"        "color_1"      "color_2"      "color_3"     
[11] "color_4"      "color_5"      "color_6"      "clarity_1"    "clarity_2"   
[16] "clarity_3"    "clarity_4"    "clarity_5"    "clarity_6"    "clarity_7"   
[21] "carat_poly_1" "carat_poly_2"

parsnip package - regression model

  • ranger()

  • ml_random_forest()

  • etc.

lm model using Basse R lm

linear_reg()

Show the code 
lm_model <-
  linear_reg() %>%
  set_mode("regression") %>%
  set_engine("lm")

fitting the lm model

Show the code 
lm_fit <- fit(lm_model,
              price ~.,
              juiced_data)

lm_fit
parsnip model object


Call:
stats::lm(formula = price ~ ., data = data)

calibrating random forest model

Show the code 
rf_fit <- rand_forest(
  mode = "regression",
  engine = "ranger",
  mtry = .preds(),
  trees = 100) %>%
  fit(price ~.,
      data = juiced_data)

rf_fit
parsnip model object

Ranger result

Call:
 ranger::ranger(x = maybe_data_frame(x), y = y, mtry = min_cols(~.preds(),      x), num.trees = ~100, num.threads = 1, verbose = FALSE, seed = sample.int(10^5,      1))

Show the code 
rf2_fit <- rand_forest(
  mode = "regression",
  engine = "randomForest",
  mtry = .preds(),
  trees = 100) %>%
  fit(price ~.,
      data = juiced_data)

lm_predicted <- augment(lm_fit$fit,
  data = juiced_data) %>%
  rowid_to_column()
  select(lm_predicted,
  rowid,
  price,
  .fitted :.std.resid)

Show the code 
price_recipe <- recipe(
  price ~ ., data = training_data) %>%
  step_log(all_outcomes()) %>%
  step_normalize(all_predictors(),
  -all_nominal()) %>%
  step_dummy(all_nominal()) %>%
  step_poly(carat, degree = 2) %>%
  prep()
Show the code 
test_data <- bake(price_recipe,
                  new_data = testing_data,
                  all_predictors())
Show the code 
lm_pred <- predict(
  lm_fit,
  new_data = test_data) %>%
  rename(lm = .pred)
Show the code 
rf_pred <- predict(
  rf_fit,
  new_data = test_data) %>%
  rename(rf = .pred)
Show the code 
test_results <- testing_data %>%
  select(price) %>%
  mutate(log_price = log(price)) %>%
  bind_cols(rf_pred) %>%
  bind_cols(lm_pred)
Show the code 
test_results %>% metrics(
  truth = log_price,
  estimate = lm)
# A tibble: 3 × 3
  .metric .estimator .estimate
  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 rmse    standard       0.160
2 rsq     standard       0.975
3 mae     standard       0.124
Show the code 
test_results %>% metrics(
  truth = log_price,
  estimate = rf)
# A tibble: 3 × 3
  .metric .estimator .estimate
  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 rmse    standard      0.108 
2 rsq     standard      0.989 
3 mae     standard      0.0803
Show the code 
metric_set(rmse, rsq, mase)
# A tibble: 3 × 3
  metric class          direction
  <chr>  <chr>          <chr>    
1 rmse   numeric_metric minimize 
2 rsq    numeric_metric maximize 
3 mase   numeric_metric minimize
Show the code 
test_results %>%
  select(c(2:4)) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    !log_price,
    names_to = "mode",
    values_to = "prediction") %>%
  group_by(model) %>%
  metrics(truth = log_price,
          estimate = prediction)
Show the code 
test_results %>%
  select(c(2:4)) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    !log_price,
    names_to = "mode",
    values_to = "prediction") %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = prediction,
             y = log_price)) +
  geom_abline(col = "green",
              lty = 2) +
  geom_point(alpha = .4) +
  facet_wrap(~model) +
  coord_fixed() +
  labs (title = "RF model predicts the diaomond prices more accurate than LM MOdel", 
        subtitle = "The diamond prices are log transformed")
